The Big Bang Fair sparking an interest in science

You don't have to visit every stand at The Big Bang Fair to understand why it has kids running around like they've had too many E numbers. In fact, it feels a little like walking into a vast sweet shop, with each stand bringing a new flavour to the mix of scientific applications on display.

Overtaking the iPad

This is the year of the tablet computer. Apple and Samsung tried to get ahead of the game late last year with the iPad and Galaxy Tab respectively, and didn't do too badly in securing a market. Apple will of course never have a problem peddling any of its crap to its swathes of drones out there, but Samsung failed fairly miserably (Thumbnail credit ADAM, the new tablet computer launched by Notion Ink)

A Farewell to Barcodes?

By James Bithell

The famous black and white stripes found on products all over the world could soon be a thing of the past, thanks to new technology currently under development in the US. The Massachusetts Institute of Technology has been working on a new form of optical tag, dubbed "bokodes," and recently revealed their innovative prototypes

Inside Kinect

Two humble physicists and their two dimensional wonder material

With the recent awarding of the Nobel Prize for Physics to Andre Geim and Konstantin Novoselov of Manchester University, I feel it justifiable to inform those who don't know about an experiment in 2004 which could, sooner rather than later, be the cause of a technological 'nano-revolution'
